Graphical abstract Metal hydroxy stannate is explored for the first time as a solid base catalyst for transesterification reactions. The catalyst was synthesized by co-precipitation method and characterized by PXRD, SEM, EDS, TGA, surface area and FT-IR measurements. In this work, we demonstrated metal hydroxy stannate as an efficient catalyst for the synthesis of biodiesel and to convert its byproduct glycerol into acetins. Performance of the catalyst was checked with both edible oil (sunflower) and non edible oils like waste cooking oil, jatropha, honge and simarouba. CaSn(OH)6 gave high biodiesel yield with the tested oils at lower reaction temperature (65°C). The performance of CaSn(OH)6 was better than other solid base catalysts like CaO, MgO, Mg/Al HTc and KF/CaO. Separation of biodiesel from un-reacted oil and glycerol was carried out using solvent extraction method and isolated yield of biodiesel was calculated. Conditions like temperature, amount of catalyst and mole ratio were studied for both the reactions to get optimum yield of end products. Fuel properties of synthesized biodiesel were tested and compared with international standards. Catalyst showed good thermal stability and reusability with consistent activity for both the reactions. Keywords Biodiesel Glycerol Methyl acetate Heterogeneous base catalyst CaSn(OH)6 Transesterification 1 Introduction Increasing demand for petroleum fuels and depleting availability of crude oil has made to look for alternative source of energy. The major challenge for scientific community is to develop a technology compatible with the existing source in terms of quality with an affordable price. Biodiesel is one such source which attracted many researchers since it can be synthesized by transesterification of vegetable oil with alcohol in presence of an acid or a base catalyst. NaOH and KOH were used as homogeneous base catalysts for biodiesel synthesis due to their high activity and affordable price. However, they cause a lot of problems such as difficulty in separation of catalyst from the product, environment problems in the catalyst disposal and more. To overcome these issues, heterogeneous catalysts were developed to make an eco-friendly process for biodiesel synthesis. Many heterogeneous acid and base catalysts were studied for transesterification reaction of oil [1]. However, solid base catalysts are more active and gave high biodiesel yield compared to acid catalysts. Solid base metal oxide catalysts like CaO, MgO, CaO/ZnO, Li/CaO and mixed metal oxides were studied extensively for transesterification of oils [2–5]. It is well-known that alkaline fluoride is a strong base catalyst but due to its homogeneous nature, it has been impregnated on various supports to heterogenize and retain basicity. Some of the reported KF loaded catalysts are KF/Al2O3, mesoporous alumina supported alkaline fluorides, KF/Zn(Al)O, KF/ZnO, KF/CaO-MgO, KF/CaO and KF/Mg-La [6–13]. Layered hydroxides (LDH) and calcined LDH were also applied as catalysts to improve the yield of methyl esters, and further basic sites were modified by varying the metal ion composition during the preparation [14,15]. Various mixed metal oxides such as Mg/Al, Mg/Zr and Mg/La were studied and they showed good activities towards transesterification reaction [16–18]. To improve the economics of biodiesel production by cutting down the cost of catalyst synthesis, waste egg shell rich in calcium was used as a catalyst [19,20]. Recently, K2CO3 impregnated on nano γ-Al2O3 and nano CaO catalysts were studied for biodiesel synthesis at higher molar ratios of oil to methanol (1:12, 1:9) [21,22]. However, many reported catalysts for transesterification of vegetable oils lacked in certain areas like low basicity, lower yields, restricted study for a particular vegetable oil, isolation of biodiesel with a proper work-up procedure. To improve the economics of biodiesel production, byproduct glycerol is also converted into value-added chemicals viz. monoacetin and diacetin using the same solid base catalyst used for biodiesel synthesis. The transesterification of glycerol with methyl acetate to acetins using solid base catalyst is studied for the first time. For the production of acetins, commonly reported acetic acid has drawbacks such as corrosion of the reactor line and generation of water as the byproduct which may harm the catalyst. Importantly, the byproduct methanol formed during glycerol transesterification reaction can be used as a reactant for biodiesel synthesis. Hence, for biodiesel synthesis, the effective process cycle by combining these two processes is the reaction of vegetable oil with methyl acetate to produce biodiesel and acetins (considering glycerol and methanol are utilized in the cycle). Monoacetin and diacetins have wide applications as raw materials for biodegradable polyesters, pharmaceuticals, food and cosmetic industries [23,24]. There are very few reports on transesterification of glycerol with methyl acetate so far in the literature. In these reports, solid acid catalysts viz. sulfonic acid functionalized SBA-15, yttrium grafted SBA-3 and poly(vinyl alcohol) (PVA) and chitosan (CH) with sulfonic acid were used under high reaction temperatures which gave a maximum of 6% selectivity for triacetin [25–27]. As homogenous biocatalysts, enzymes like lipid and novozym were applied to synthesize acetins [28,29]. The transesterification of glycerol with ethyl acetate was also studied using solid acid catalysts (amberlyst-15 & 16) under high temperatures to get di and triacetin and ethanol as a byproduct [30]. This study aimed at designing a novel strong solid base catalyst for transesterification of vegetable oil with methanol and transesterification of methyl acetate with glycerol to get high yields for biodiesel with properties meeting the international standards and glycerol acetins respectively. It is well known that calcium oxide is basic in nature which is used extensively as a catalyst for base catalyzed reactions in pure oxide or mixed oxide forms. In this work, Ca and Sn mixed metal hydroxide is reported as a strong solid base catalyst and used for the transesterification of both edible and non-edible oils to their corresponding fatty acid methyl esters (FAME). Previously we reported zinc hydroxystannate as a bifunctional catalyst for carbonylation of glycerol with urea [31] This crystalline double perovskite hydroxide exhibits alternating cations, which are octahedrally co-ordinated with oxygen atoms to form Ca(OH)6 and Sn(OH)6 polyhedra (Fig. 1 ) [32]. The CaSn(OH)6 is for the first time applied as a solid base catalyst for transesterification reactions of vegetable oil and glycerol to produce biodiesel and acetins respectively. In this study, the overall idea of carrying out both the reactions simultaneously is to make biodiesel synthesis more economical by converting its byproduct glycerol into value-added chemicals like monoacetin and diacetin (Scheme 1 ). Methyl acetate being a non toxic chemical is used as a reactant for esterification of glycerol using the base catalyst. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials Glycerol, methyl acetate, methanol, calcium chloride, zinc chloride, strontium chloride, tin (IV) chloride, potassium fluoride, calcium oxide (CaO), calcium hydroxide Ca(OH)2, magnesium oxide (MgO), magnesium nitrate, aluminum nitrate, sodium hydroxide pellets and sodium carbonate were purchased from Merck India Ltd. All the chemicals were of research grade and used without any further purification. Vegetable oils like sunflower, honge, simarouba, jatropha were purchased from local suppliers and waste cooking oil (WCO) was used from the institute canteen. 2.2 Catalyst preparation CaSn(OH)6 was prepared by co-precipitation of respective calcium and tin salts. In a typical procedure, equimolar quantities of calcium chloride and tin(IV) chloride were dissolved in water. Sodium hydroxide was added drop-wise to this solution until a complete precipitation occurred. The resulted white precipitate was stirred for 2h at room temperature, filtered and washed thoroughly until free from chloride ions and dried in an oven at 150°C for 6h to get CaSn(OH)6. To get more insight on its properties, CaSn(OH)6 was converted into its oxide by calcining at 800°C for 5h (named as calcium tin oxide). Generation of basic sites in oxides requires high pre-treatment temperature. Hence, CaO, MgO, calcium tin oxide were calcined at 800°C for 5h before use [33]. KF/CaO was synthesized by wet impregnation method, where KF was loaded on CaO. In a typical procedure, 10ml of aqueous solution containing 17mmol KF was mixed with 1g of CaO under vigorous stirring at room temperature for 2h followed by the evaporation of water at 80°C in a water bath. Then it was dried in an oven at 120°C overnight and calcined under air at 600°C for 4h. To remove any physisorbed KF present on the support, the catalyst was placed in 50ml distilled water, stirred well, filtered and dried at 120°C. MgAl hydrotalcite (HTc/MgAl) was prepared by the co-precipitation method. Firstly, Mg(NO3)2 and Al(NO3)3 (total 0.372mol) were dissolved in 187ml of distilled water. Then, this solution was added slowly into a 90ml aqueous solution of 0.1125mol of Na2CO3, which was then poured into a conical flask and heated to 60°C. During co-precipitation, the slurry was vigorously stirred with a magnet bar and kept at pH 10 by the dropwise addition of a 0.437mol solution of NaOH. After complete addition of the metal nitrates solution, the suspension was stirred at 60°C for 1h followed by ageing for 18h without stirring at the same temperature. The synthesized solid was washed, filtered, dried at 80°C for 16h. It was then ground into a fine powder and calcined in air at 500°C for 16h to produce hydrotalcite. 2.3 Catalyst characterization XRD data of all the prepared catalysts were collected at room temperature by using Bruker D2 Phaser diffractometer in Bragg-Brentano geometry equipped with a high resolution LynxEye detector. Cu Kα radiation (λ=1.5418Å) was used and data were collected from 2θ=5 to 80° with a step size of 0.02°. To investigate the functional groups and the chemical property of the synthesized catalyst, infrared transmittance spectra were recorded in the range 500–4000cm−1 by FT-IR spectrophotometer (alpha–T, Bruker). Both ATR and KBr pellet techniques were applied for determining the IR spectra of the samples. To analyze the impurity level of sodium in the sample, atomic absorption spectroscopy measurement was conducted using AAnalyst 200 (Perkin Elmer) instrument. The thermal stability of the CaSn(OH)6 catalyst was determined by TGA studies using Shimadzu DTG-60 thermal analysis system. SEM (Ultra 55Carl Zeiss FE-SEM) with EDS was performed to identify the morphology, particle size and elemental analysis of CaSn(OH)6–fresh, CaSn(OH)6–reused, MgSn(OH)6 and ZnSn(OH)6 catalysts. The specific surface areas of the catalysts were measured by N2 physisorption at liquid nitrogen temperature on Belsorb Mini II at 77K and using the standard BET method on the basis of adsorption data. The basicity of all the solid base catalysts was analyzed qualitatively using Hammett indicators such as neutral red (pKBH+ 6.8–8.0), phenolphthalein (pKBH+ 8.0–9.6), nile blue (pKBH+ 10.1–11.1) and tropaeolin-0 (pKBH+ 11.1–12.7). The quantitative estimation of basicity was performed by titration method using benzoic acid [30]. For leachable basicity measurement, the catalyst (0.5g) was shaken in water (50ml) for 1h at room temperature, filtered and a methanol solution of nile blue/phenolphthalein (5ml, 0.1mg/ml) was added to the filtrate. It was titrated with methanolic solution of benzoic acid (0.01M) to determine the leached basic sites. The fuel properties namely, density (kgm−3), viscosity (mm2 s−1), calorific value (MJkg−1), flash point (°C), fire point (°C) and ash content (wt%) of synthesized biodiesel were determined by following the American standards, D4052, D446, D240, D93, D97 and D482 respectively, and also compared with the Indian (IS15607), American (D6751) and European (EN12414) biodiesel standards. 2.4 Catalytic activity 2.4.1 Synthesis of biodiesel a) Estimation of acid value and esterification of vegetable oil to decrease the free acid content: Standard method was followed as per European standard EN14104. b) Transesterification of different oils with methanol: a two necked round bottom flask was charged with the oil and preheated at 65°C for one hour with continuous stirring. After one hour, the catalyst and methanol were added to the mixture with continuous stirring at 65°C for 6–14h depending on the type of oil taken. The parameters affecting the transesterification reaction such as catalyst weight% (1–5wt%), oil to methanol molar ratio (1: 3–1: 14), reaction time (1–9h) were determined to optimize the reaction with sunflower oil as the feedstock. c) Isolation of biodiesel procedure: after the reaction, the catalyst was separated from the reaction mixture by centrifugation. The separation of biodiesel was carried out using the following procedure. Product mixture contained glycerol at the bottom and methyl esters at the top with impurities of unreacted oil and methanol of which the latter was removed first by distillation. This two layered mixture was taken in a separating funnel and petroleum ether (30–50ml) was added, shaken well and allowed to settle for one hour. Glycerol at the bottom was removed as a separate layer and weighed. Petroleum ether was distilled out from the top layer to obtain total esters. Methanol (20–30ml) was then added to the total ester in which biodiesel was completely miscible leaving un-reacted oil as a separate layer. This mixture was allowed to settle in the separating funnel for an hour and un-reacted oil layer at the bottom was removed and weighed. Then methanol was distilled out from the biodiesel layer to get pure biodiesel [34,35]. The methyl esters were identified by gas chromatography with mass spectroscopy (Shimadzu, GCMS QP 2010). The oil conversion (%) and yields of biodiesel were calculated using the formula, Oil Conversion (%) =[wt. of glycerol produced actually/wt. of glycerol produced stochiometrically]×100 Biodiesel Yield (%) =[wt. of biodiesel produced/wt. of oil taken for the reaction]×100 [Note: wt. of oil taken/mol. wt. of oil is directly proportional to the moles of glycerol×mol. Wt. of glycerol=wt. of glycerol produced stoichiometrically]. 2.4.2 Synthesis of acetins Transesterification reaction of methyl acetate with glycerol was carried out in a 100ml two–necked glass reactor equipped with a magnetic stirring bar, a Liebig condenser, and a thermometer. The required amounts of glycerol and methyl acetate were taken in the glass reactor and catalyst was added into it. The reaction was performed under stirring at a desired temperature. After the reaction, the mixture was taken out and centrifuged for 10min to separate the catalyst from liquid phase. The obtained product was analyzed by gas chromatography (Shimadzu, GC–2014) with flame ionization detector (FID) equipped with capillary column (0.25mm I.D and 30m length, Stabilwax, Restek). Identities of all the products were confirmed by gas chromatography with mass spectroscopy (Shimadzu, GCMS QP 2010). The product yield was calculated by the GC analysis using the formula, Product yield (mol%)=[Conversion (mol%)×Selectivity (mol%)]/100. 2.4.3 Procedure for catalyst leaching and recycle experiment Leaching tests for the transesterification reactions of oil with methanol and methyl acetate with glycerol were carried out to investigate the leaching of any active species from the catalyst into reaction media. The transesterification reaction of sunflower oil was carried out using CaSn(OH)6 catalyst at a reaction temperature of 65°C with oil to methanol mole ratio of 1:10. Reaction was stopped after 30min and the hot reaction mixture containing catalyst was centrifuged. Supernated liquid was taken and the reaction was continued for another 5h. Further, leaching test for transesterification of glycerol with methyl acetate was also conducted at 30°C with glycerol to methyl acetate mole ratio of 1:20. Reaction was stopped after 15min and the reaction mixture was centrifuged. The reaction was continued for another 5h by taking supernated liquid. For both the biodiesel and acetin syntheses, catalyst reusability was tested for 5 recycles. After each run, the catalyst was separated from the reaction mixture by filtration, washed thoroughly with methanol, dried at 120°C and reused with fresh reactants under same reaction conditions as mentioned in Table 3. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 X-ray diffraction studies All the diffraction peaks in the PXRD pattern could be indexed to cubic CaSn(OH)6 with a lattice parameter a, b, c=8.135 Ǻ and confirmed that the material crystallizes with space group Pn3- according to the standard XRD data file source (ICDS=#25825). The XRD pattern of CaSn(OH)6 shows major diffraction peaks at 2θ (°) values of 19.6, 22.6, 32.5, 36.2, 38.4, 40.1, 46.7, 52.4 and 57.8 which can be ascribed to the hkl reflections (111), (200), (220), (310), (311), (222), (400), (420) and (422) planes of cubic CaSn(OH)6 respectively (Fig. 2 ). XRD patterns of all the other synthesized catalysts matched well with ICSD patterns. PXRD patterns of all the other prepared catalysts are shown in ESI (Figs. S1 and S2). 3.2 FT-IR analysis FT–IR spectrum was recorded from 500 to 4000cm−1 for CaSn(OH)6, calcium tin oxide and recycled CaSn(OH)6 catalysts (Fig. 3 ). CaSn(OH)6 catalyst gave a spectrum containing a strong band at 3200cm−1 due to the OH stretching vibration and those at 800 and 1165cm−1 correspond to OH bending vibrations [36]. The calcium tin oxide showed lattice vibration of CaO at 515cm−1 and peak 590cm−1 shows the stretching vibration of O-Sn-O. Absorption band at 878cm−1 is due the presence of carbonate species formed during the exposure of catalyst surface to air during calcinations. The strong peak at 1526cm−1 is attributed to symmetric stretching vibration of unidentate carbonate [37,38]. The FT-IR analysis confirms the structure with the presence of OH groups in CaSn(OH)6 and the absence of OH groups in calcium tin oxide catalyst as shown in Fig. 3. 3.3 Thermal analysis The thermal stability of CaSn(OH)6 catalyst was determined by TGA studies (Fig. 4 ). Interestingly, there was only 0.5% weight loss up to 250°C which indicates the presence of very low amount of water of hydration in CaSn(OH)6. This property of low hygroscopicity is very useful for any base catalysts, where it is not necessary to maintain moisture free conditions for carrying out reactions. Also the material has reasonably good thermal stability of ∼250°C and can be used for the reaction below this temperature. The weight loss in CaSn(OH)6 started after 250°C with a rapid loss of hydroxyl groups which led to the formation of oxide. 3.4 SEM and elemental analysis SEM analysis was performed to identify the morphology and particle size of CaSn(OH)6. The catalyst exhibited a uniform morphology of cuboid shape with 1–4μm particle size (Fig. 5 a). Elemental analysis of MSn(OH)6 [M=Ca, Mg and Zn] catalyst was performed by EDS analysis (ESI Table S1). Since NaOH was used in the catalyst preparation, it is important to know if the sodium is present in the catalyst as an impurity. The EDS elemental analysis showed the absence of sodium in the samples and the spectrum shows that the probable location of the Na is as low as the noise peaks as in Fig. 6 (except for ZnSn(OH)6 where Zn and Na peaks could not be distinguished). To know the total amount of sodium present in the catalyst, AAS analysis was also performed for CaSn(OH)6 which showed very low concentration of 0.003% Na. 3.5 BET surface area measurements The N2 sorption measurement for all the catalysts showed varied surface areas. Among the catalysts, CaSn(OH)6 and KF/CaO showed very low surface areas of 3.95 and 3.79m2/g respectively. Surface areas of all the hydroxide catalysts were <18m2/g, whereas other base catalysts viz. HTc(Mg/Al), CaO and MgO showed surface area of 86, 64 and 44m2/g respectively (Table 1 ). 3.6 Basicity measurements Basicity of all the solid base catalysts was determined by Hammett indicator method and the values are tabulated in Table 1. The conventional solid base catalysts such as Mg/Al HTc, CaO and MgO showed basicity (pKBH+) in the range 8.0–9.6 with a color change for phenolphthalein but not for nile blue. The change in color from nile blue to pink in CaSn(OH)6 indicated the strength of basicity (pKBH+) in the range 10.1–11.1. It also showed a color change for phenolphthalein indicator from colorless to pink (pKBH+ 8.0–9.6) which indicates that CaSn(OH)6 has basicity of two different strengths. Similarly, MgSn(OH)6, SrSn(OH)6 and KF/CaO also exhibited two basic strengths corresponding to nile blue and phenolphthalein indicators. Among all hydroxy stannate catalysts, ZnSn(OH)6 showed color change only for nile blue (pKBH+ 10.1–11.1). Quantitative estimation showed that, CaSn(OH)6, MgSn(OH)6, SrSn(OH)6 and KF/CaO contained basicities of 22, 23, 15 and 24μmol/g corresponding to phenolphthalein indicator and 7, 11, 3 and 5μmol/g for nile blue indicator respectively, whereas ZnSn(OH)6 showed basicity of 33μmol/g corresponding to nile blue. Mg/Al HTc, Ca(OH)2, CaO and MgO showed the basicities of 26, 19, 18 and 13μmol/g respectively (only for phenolphthalein indicator). The calcination of CaSn(OH)6 to 800°C under air forming calcium tin oxide decreased the basicity from 22 to 18μmol/g. In general, it is found that basic strengths of conventional solid base catalysts taken in this study were lower than metal hydroxystannate. Furthermore, no leachable basicity in aqueous solution was observed for all the solid catalysts. 3.7 Catalytic activity measurements 3.7.1 Transesterification of edible oil The efficiency of the CaSn(OH)6 catalyst was compared with other solid base catalysts using refined sunflower oil with the estimated acid value of 0.2%. In this study, the solid base catalysts used are KF/CaO, CaO, MgO and Mg/Al HTc, which are reported in the literatures as active catalysts for transesterification reaction. Activity of these catalysts and CaSn(OH)6 for the transesterification of sunflower oil with methanol is shown in Table 2 . The catalysts with basicity>20μmol/g for phenolphthalein indicator showed oil conversion above 85%. The catalysts, HTc (Mg/Al), Ca(OH)2, CaO and MgO having basicity in the decreasing order converted oil also in the decreasing order (86, 82, 74, 71% respectively). Among all the catalysts, CaSn(OH)6 gave the highest oil conversion (96%) and biodiesel yield (94%). KF impregnated on CaO improved the performance of CaO to 90% with improved basicity of 24 and 5μmol/g with respect to phenolphthalein and nile blue. The activity of CaSn(OH)6 was compared with the other synthesized metal hydroxy stannates (Table 2). MgSn(OH)6, ZnSn(OH)6 and SrSn(OH)6 with basicities of 7, 11 and 3μmol/g for nile blue and 22, 23 and 15μmol/g for phenolphthalein, correspondingly showed oil conversion of 96, 92 and 65% respectively. ZnSn(OH)6 with estimated basicity for nile blue of 33μmol/g showed 72% of oil conversion. The lower activity of ZnSn(OH)6 could be attributed to Lewis acidic zinc which may affect the performance of the catalyst. The calcination of CaSn(OH)6 to calcium tin oxide decreased the basicity from 22 to 20μmol/g, and hence conversion decreased from 96 to 88%. Overall results of oil conversion show that calcium has an influential role on the strength and basicity of the catalyst and also the presence of hydroxyl groups increased the activity of the catalyst. 3.7.2 Transesterification of non edible oils As CaSn(OH)6 catalyst gave higher conversion for sunflower oil compared to all other solid base catalysts tested in this study, it was selected as a best catalyst for further studies on biodiesel synthesis. Different non-edible oils such as honge, jatropha, simarouba and waste cooking oil were used for biodiesel synthesis from the newly developed catalyst. The acid value of these oils was found to be higher than 2%. To reduce the acid value, esterification of these oils was performed and the resultant oil with reduced acid value was used for transesterification. Table 3 shows the acid value before and after the esterification, biodiesel yield and reaction time. Non edible crude oils contained high acid value from 7.5 to 14.3 except for waste cooking oil. After esterification, acid values reduced to <2%. CaSn(OH)6 showed excellent performance for all the studied non-edible oils with >90% biodiesel yield with only 3wt% catalyst. This shows the general applicability of this catalyst for variety of vegetable oils including highly potential source of non-edible oil, jatropha for commercial exploitation. The effective blending of synthesized biodiesel with diesel was checked with FT–IR spectrum, where the FT-IR data was collected for all the biodiesel products synthesized by different oils and matched with commercial diesel. The bands at 720–725cm−1 are associated to CH rocking band vibration. Stretching vibrations of CO are observed at 1100cm−1 and stretching & bending vibrations of CH2 and CH3 are observed in the band range of 1370–1378cm−1 and 1450–1470cm−1 respectively. The band of peak max. 1800cm−1 corresponds to the stretching of CO, whereas CH stretching is observed at band range of 2850–3000cm−1. The band range of 1450–1470cm−1 and 2850–3000cm−1 of biodiesel matched well with the diesel fuel band. In other words, the synthesized biodiesel can be used as a blend with diesel. The CH stretching frequency at 2850–3000cm−1 and CH2 bending vibrations at 1450–1470cm−1 of diesel were matched with biodiesel peaks to confirm the conversion of triglycerides to methyl esters. Other than CH stretching, CO stretching vibrations at 1800cm−1 and CO at 1100cm−1 were also observed for biodiesel synthesized by oils as shown in Fig. 7 . 3.7.3 Transestrification of glycerol with methyl acetate Transesterification of glycerol with methyl acetate to form mono and diacetin was carried out using synthesized solid base catalysts. Among all the catalysts, CaSn(OH)6 catalyst showed maximum glycerol conversion of 78.2% and other hydroxy stannates MSn(OH)6 (M=Mg, Zn, Sr) gave conversions of 65.4, 40, 25.2% respectively. The other solid base catalysts like KF/CaO, Mg/Al HTc, CaO and MgO exhibited glycerol conversion of 69, 68.5, 47.2 and 25.2 respectively (Table 2). The catalysts with higher basicity showed higher glycerol conversion with high selectivity towards monoacetin. The selectivity for diacetin was high for metal hydroxy stannates compared with conventional solid base catalysts except for KF/CaO. High activity and selectivity for diacetin for metal hydroxy stannate, in particular, CaSn(OH)6 could be attributed to the presence of stronger basicity (Hammett basicity for nile blue). CaSn(OH)6 upon calcination to 800°C lost the basicity by converting into oxide form, and hence activity decreased. CaSn(OH)6 was selected as the best catalyst among the catalysts tested and taken for further study. To get more insight into the relation between conversion and product selectivity, the reactions were conducted under suitable conditions to achieve similar glycerol conversions for different solid base catalysts. All the catalysts with the glycerol conversions between 64.0 and 68.2% gave varied selectivities for mono and diacetins (Table 4 ). CaSn(OH)6 catalyst (3wt%) gave 76.6% selectivity for monoacetin and 22.7% selectivity for diacetin in 15min, whereas MgO gave similar performance at higher catalyst concentration of 14wt% in 270min reaction time. The catalysts like KF/CaO, HTc (Mg/Al), Ca(OH)2 and CaO showed low selectivity for diacetin (<10%) at similar conversions. The metal tin hydroxides exhibited higher selectivity for diacetin (<20%) compared to other solid base catalysts except MgO. These results show that the mono and diacetin selectivity is independent of glycerol conversion but it depends mainly on the nature of active sites present in the catalyst. Transesterification reaction was also performed with the glycerol produced during the biodiesel synthesis using CaSn(OH)6 catalyst. The conversion of this crude glycerol was 68% with 78% monoacetin and 22% diacetin selectivities. Thus compared to commercial glycerol, the crude form gave 10% lower conversion which could be attributed to the impurities present in it. 3.8 Optimization of reaction conditions 3.8.1 Transesterification of vegetable oil The reaction conditions were optimized to achieve maximum yield of biodiesel using sunflower oil. The effect of temperature, mole ratio and catalyst wt% were studied for sunflower oil with CaSn(OH)6 catalyst. The reaction temperature was varied from 45 to 75°C and the results are shown in Fig. 8 a. The results suggest that the conversion of oil increases with the increase in the temperature from 45 to 65°C. At 45°C, the oil conversion was 35% which increased to 95% upon increase in the temperature to 65°C. Since 75°C is above the reflux temperature, the reaction was performed using a stirred pressure autoclave which gave a marginally increased conversion of 97%. But the reflux temperature of 65°C was found to be suitable temperature for getting maximum biodiesel yield under atmospheric pressure conditions in a simple glass reactor set-up. Important variable affecting the yield of ester is the catalyst concentration which was varied from 1 to 5wt% keeping the temperature at 65°C and oil to methanol mole ratio of 1:10. Upon increasing the catalyst wt% from 1 to 3, the conversion increased substantially and further increase in catalyst concentration resulted in only a marginal increase in the conversion of sunflower oil and the results are shown in Fig. 8b. Hence, catalyst concentration of 3wt% with respect to the oil weight is found to be the optimum to get high biodiesel yield. The effect of mole ratio was studied for sunflower oil with CaSn(OH)6 at 65°C and 3wt% catalyst. The stoichiometry of the transesterification reaction requires 3mol of alcohol per mole of triglyceride to yield 3mol of methyl fatty esters and 1mol of glycerol. To shift the transesterification reaction to the right, it is necessary to use a large excess of alcohol, and hence the mole ratio of oil to methanol was varied from 1:3 to 1:14 (Fig. 8c). At lower mole ratio, the oil conversion was poor and as the mole ratio was increased to 1:10, the conversion increased to the maximum of 98%. A marginal increase in conversion was observed upon increasing mole ratio further to 1:14. So in this study, 1:10 is considered to be the optimum mole ratio to get high conversion of sunflower oil. Since each experiment needs a work-up to get the conversion and yield, effect of reaction time was studied independently by carrying out transesterification for 1–5h under the identical conditions (65°C, catalyst concentration of 3wt%, oil: methanol of 1:10) for sunflower oil using CaSn(OH)6 catalyst. The results of the study are shown in Fig. 9 a. With an increase in reaction time, yield of biodiesel increased gradually and it remained constant after some point. From the reaction, it is clear that 3h is the optimum time for the reaction to get maximum yield. Once the reaction mixture is saturated with the product, a small amount of unreacted oil may not be able to interact with the catalyst active sites. Hence, the biodiesel yield marginally increased after 3h of reaction time. 3.8.2 Transesterification of glycerol with methyl acetate The effect of glycerol to methyl acetate mole ratio was studied for CaSn(OH)6 catalyst to get better yield of acetins at room temperature (30°C). Glycerol to methyl acetate mole ratio was varied from 1:2 to 1:20 to get high yield of acetins. The conversion increased with increase in mole ratio from 1:2 to 1:10. The maximum glycerol conversion achieved was around 78% for 1:10mol ratio. Further increase in the mole ratio gave high monoacetin selectivity but the conversion remained the same. So 1:10mol ratio was optimum to get high glycerol conversion (Fig. 10 ). The catalyst weight was optimized from 3 to 10wt% referred to total reactant weight. With increase in catalyst weight from 3 to 7wt%, the conversion increased from 52 to 78%, whereas further increase to 10wt% resulted in only a marginal increase of conversion (Fig. 11 ). Effect of reaction time on transesterification of glycerol with methyl acetate was studied under the optimized reaction conditions (Fig. 9b) at room temperature. The glycerol conversion was 70% at 30min and increased to 78% after 2h reaction time. The conversion remained almost the same with further increase in reaction time to 5h. This could be due to the product saturation in the reaction mixture which may hinder the active site accessibility to the less polar reactant, methyl acetate (acetins and byproduct methanol are more polar than methyl acetate). Maximum diacetin selectivity of 33% was achieved for this catalyst. 3.9 Fuel properties of methyl esters All the synthesized biodiesel products from both edible and non edible oils were tested for fuel properties and compared with BIS, ASTM and DIN standards. Fuel properties like specific gravity, viscosity, flash point, fire point, ash content were measured for all the biodiesel products. All the required properties were well within the limits as per the international standards as represented in Table 5 . This study indicates that the biodiesel products obtained from different vegetable oils are fit to use as such or as the blend with diesel for commercial applications. The post synthesis work-up carried out in this study is particularly helped in getting the pure biodiesel products of standard quality. 3.10 Leaching and reusability test The transesterification reaction of oil with methanol using CaSn(OH)6 showed 45% conversion for 30min. The reaction was continued to 5h after the removal of catalyst from the reaction mixture, which gave almost the same conversion (47%). Further, leaching test for transesterification of glycerol with methyl acetate was conducted. The reaction gave 25% glycerol conversion with CaSn(OH)6 catalyst after 15min. The reaction was further continued for another 5h in the absence of the catalyst which showed negligible increase in conversion (26%). Thus, both the reactions indicated no leaching of active sites into the reaction media. The reusability study was conducted with CaSn(OH)6 catalyst for both the transesterification of sunflower oil and for glycerol reactions. The test was performed up to 5 successive cycles for both the reactions. The catalyst showed consistent performance with only a marginal decrease in activity of 6% for oil conversion and 2% glycerol conversion (Fig. 12 ). Interestingly, the catalyst without regeneration at high temperatures was able to retain the activity after successive reuse. Furthermore, XRD patterns and FT-IR spectrum of both fresh and recycled catalysts for transesterification of vegetable oil indicated that there was no change in phase purity after the five recycles (Figs. 13 and 3 ). Also, XRD pattern and FT-IR spectrum of reused catalyst matched well with that of the fresh catalyst for transesterification of glycerol. The SEM image of reused CaSn(OH)6 catalyst showed that the cuboid morphology of the particles was retained even after 5 successive cycles (Fig. 5b). Furthermore, the elemental analysis of recycled catalyst by EDS (Fig. 6) showed that the compositions of fresh and recycled catalysts were almost the same (Table S1). 4 Conclusions Metal hydroxy stannate is reported for the first time as a strong solid base catalyst for biodiesel and acetin synthesis under mild reaction conditions. The CaSn(OH)6 catalyst was thermally stable upto 250°C with low hygroscopicity exhibiting the morphology of cuboid shape with particle size of 6–10μm. XRD and FTIR studies confirmed the structure of the catalyst with the presence of OH groups. Estimation of basicity by Hammett Indicator method showed that CaSn(OH)6 has a strong basicity. Catalytic activity of CaSn(OH)6 is more efficient than other heterogeneous catalysts in biodiesel synthesis with the biodiesel yield of 94% for sunflower oil. Further, the application of the catalyst was extended to synthesize biodiesel from different non-edible oils as feedstock after the reduction of acid value from 7 to 14% to less than 2%. Catalyst also showed its capability in synthesizing biodiesel from different non-edible oils with the yield>90% for 9–14h of reaction time. Physical properties of biodiesel synthesized from various vegetable oils were in the range prescribed by ASTM standards. The catalyst showed a good performance for transesterification of glycerol with methyl acetate to give di and mono acetins. The glycerol conversion of 78% was achieved in 2h reaction time with 67% selectivity for monoacetin and 33% selectivity for diacetin at room temperature. This is the first report for carrying out transesterification of glycerol with methyl acetate using a solid base catalyst. The catalyst showed good activity for 5 cycles of reuse without regeneration at higher temperatures. The authors thank Metrohm India Limited, Chennai for surface area measurements and REVA College of engineering, Bengaluru for measuring the fuel properties of all the biodiesel samples. coredata.dc:description: Metal hydroxy stannate is explored for the first time as a solid base catalyst for transesterification reactions. The catalyst was synthesized by co-precipitation method and characterized by PXRD, SEM, EDS, TGA, surface area and FT-IR measurements. In this work, we demonstrated metal hydroxy stannate as an efficient catalyst for the synthesis of biodiesel and to convert its byproduct glycerol into acetins. Performance of the catalyst was checked with both edible oil (sunflower) and non edible oils like waste cooking oil, jatropha, honge and simarouba. CaSn(OH)6 gave high biodiesel yield with the tested oils at lower reaction temperature (65°C). The performance of CaSn(OH)6 was better than other solid base catalysts like CaO, MgO, Mg/Al HTc and KF/CaO. Separation of biodiesel from un-reacted oil and glycerol was carried out using solvent extraction method and isolated yield of biodiesel was calculated. Conditions like temperature, amount of catalyst and mole ratio were studied for both the reactions to get optimum yield of end products. Fuel properties of synthesized biodiesel were tested and compared with international standards. Catalyst showed good thermal stability and reusability with consistent activity for both the reactions.
coredata.dc:title: Synthesis of biodiesel and acetins by transesterification reactions using novel CaSn(OH)6 heterogeneous base catalyst​
